Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Molly C. Womack
Proposal number: 1611752

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Molly C. Womack is 'Selection and Constraints on Evolution of the Anuran Skeleton' The host institutions for this fellowship are the University of California-Berkeley and the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History, and the sponsoring scientists are Dr. Erica Bree Rosenblum (UC-Berkeley) and Dr. Rayna Bell (Smithsonian).

The goal of this research is to identify selection pressures and evolutionary limitations acting on the skeleton diversity of frogs (anurans) over 160 million years of evolution. The Fellow is using X-ray microtomography (micro-CT) to examine the skeletons of 200 genera, spanning all 55 families of frogs. Using this dataset, the Fellow is analyzing the co-evolution of traits and providing a comprehensive study of anuran skeleton diversity. Despite the vast diversity of forms seen in nature, particular phenotypes evolve repeatedly across both closely related and deeply divergent species (convergent evolution). Frogs show rampant convergence and provide an exceptional system for researching the constraints and selection pressures that dictate evolutionary convergence as well as the limits of morphological evolution. The Fellow is using collections at the UC-Berkeley Museum of Vertebrate Zoology and the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History to generate a dataset to understand convergent evolution and evolutionary development. The 3D models of 200 anuran skeletons are being made freely available to other researchers and the public, allowing future studies to easily collect morphological data from museum specimens without destruction of any curated specimens. In addition to the proposed research, the Fellow is utilizing this extensive dataset to highlight species and clades of frogs that would provide ideal comparisons for future research investigating the evolution of skeletal traits.

The Fellow is receiving training in micro-CT methods and comparative phylogenetic analyses. The Fellow is collaborating with both the Berkeley Natural History Museums Project and the Smithsonian's Q?rius program to create and implement lessons to communicate concepts such as adaptation and convergent evolution to broad audiences. These lessons use interactive 3D models of museum specimen skeletons that the Fellow is generating, and that are being made freely available for teachers and the general public through the Berkeley Natural History Museums Project and Q?rius websites. The Fellow is also mentoring multiple undergraduate researchers on the manipulation and quantification of 3D data as well as data for comparative phylogenetic analyses. These undergraduate researchers also have access to the broad dataset generated by the Fellow's research, for use in independent research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this two year postdoctoral fellowship, the PI accomplished the proposed project and in doing so generated whole-skeleton micro-CT data for over 250 frog species using museum specimens from the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology and National Museum of Natural History. This work has provided the first comprehensive study of anuran skeleton diversity and evaluated how the anuran skeleton has adapted to habitats worldwide over 200 million years of evolution. Detailed analysis of skeletal structures has revealed previously unappreciated morphological diversity not characterized by current comparative studies. Specific studies from this research include highlighting the upper limits on anuran skeleton size and investigating constraints on the evolution of anuran vertebrae and limb proportions. Results from this project have been reported in six invited seminars and three scientific conferences (the 2017 NSF Collections-Based PRFB Symposium in Cambridge, MA, the 2018 iDigBio Conference in Berkeley, California, and the 2018 Evolution Conference in Montpellier, France). The PI will continue to disseminate these results through manuscripts (four currently in prep) as well as future conferences (the 2019 International Congress of Vertebrate Morphology and the 2019 Evolution Meetings). The dataset generated by the PI will provide a jumping point for future research in convergent evolution and evolutionary development studies. The PI will continue to leverage this extensive dataset to highlight species and clades of anurans that provide ideal comparisons for future research investigating how an animal's genetic blueprint and early development determine an animal's adult form.

 

Furthermore, findings from this study have been communicated to K-12 students and broader, public audiences through interactive exhibits at "Save the Frogs Day" at the University of California, Berkeley and Q?rius at National Museum of Natural History, Washington DC using the 3D skeletons generated from the research projects. In addition, the PI successfully trained and mentored six undergraduate researchers and one high school student throughout the two-year project. These students learned how to generate testable hypotheses, manipulate and analyze 3D data in a phylogenetic framework, and write for a scientific audience. Four of these mentees are currently first-author on manuscripts in prep, one student presented a poster on her work at the 2018 iDigBio Conference in Berkeley, California, one student has started as a Masters student in Evolutionary Biology, and another student has taken a job working on anuran reintroductions and conservation. 

 

In addition to all of these accomplishments, the PI published 4 peer-reviewed articles (Womack et al. 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Womack et al. 2018 Evolution; Womack et al. 2018 Journal of Experimental Biology; Womack et al. 2018 Journal of Morphology) and submitted 2 more manuscripts that are now in revision for American Naturalistand Journal of Evolutionary Biology. To build on the projects performed during this NSF fellowship, the PI was awarded a Peter Buck Postdoctoral Fellowship at the National Museum of Natural History as well as the Secretary's Distinguished Fellowship at the National Museum of Natural History. The PI also received and accepted an Assistant Professor position at Utah State University.

Modified by: Molly C Womack
